Abstract:

Title: The extracellular matrix as a mediator of cell-cell communication in cardiovascular inflammation

The MATRICARD project stands at the forefront of cardiovascular research, aiming to unravel the complex role of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in mediating cell-cell communication during the progression of cardiovascular diseases (CVD), including coronary artery disease (CAD), myocardial infarction (MI), and heart failure. The project addresses the urgent need to better understand CVD, the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, affecting both industrialized and developing countries.

Rooted in the concept that ECM proteins, beyond providing structural support, serve as crucial communication hubs and transducers of mechanical stimuli, MATRICARD focuses on the interplay between genetic variations in ECM proteins and their association with inflammatory processes in CVD. A comprehensive exploration of the ECM proteome in sterile inflammatory diseases like atherosclerosis will be conducted to uncover novel regulatory molecules and understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms influencing both chronic and acute disease courses.

The project's research aims are multifaceted: to delve into the ECM proteome in sterile inflammatory diseases, identify novel regulators, elucidate underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms, and develop individualized treatment strategies. Through its innovative approach, MATRICARD endeavors to advance knowledge beyond technical boundaries, identify novel therapeutic targets, and translate these findings into human clinical trials.

The potential outcomes of MATRICARD are transformative. By exploring the ECM's role in the context of leukocytes, endothelial cells, vascular smooth muscle cells, platelets, fibroblasts, and cardiomyocytes, the project is poised to reveal deep insights into ECM-mediated cell-cell communication and its translation potential, offering a beacon of hope for personalized medicine in the fight against CVD.

Keywords: cardiovascular diseases, extracellular matrix, cell-cell communication, inflammation, genetic variation, therapeutic targets, personalized medicine.

Abstract

Title: The Extracellular Matrix as a Mediator of Cell-Cell Communication in Cardiovascular Inflammation (Project MATRICARD)

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), including coronary artery disease (CAD), myocardial infarction (MI), and heart failure, are leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Atherosclerosis, often a consequence of sterile inflammation, is the primary pathology underlying CAD and MI. The extracellular matrix (ECM) plays a crucial role in the regulation of cell behaviors and has been implicated in the progression of CVDs. This project, named MATRICARD, aims to elucidate the role of the ECM as a communication hub, transducing mechanical stimuli and mediating cell-cell interaction signals in the context of cardiovascular inflammation.

The MATRICARD project will investigate the ECM proteome in sterile inflammatory diseases such as CAD and MI, identify novel regulators and understanding underlying processes, and study molecular and cellular mechanisms affecting disease course. By focusing on genetic variations influencing ECM proteins, we aim to uncover the association between ECM alterations and CVDs. The project's goals are to advance beyond current technical boundaries, deepen our knowledge of ECM-mediated cell-cell communication, and assess the translational potential of our findings.

Our research aims include exploring the ECM proteome, identifying novel regulators, studying molecular and cellular mechanisms, developing new therapeutic targets, and translating these findings to human clinical trials. We expect to reveal novel individualized treatment strategies and adapt these strategies for clinical trials, significantly impacting the management of patients with cardiovascular diseases.

By exploring the multifaceted roles of ECM in CVDs, MATRICARD will contribute to a deeper understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms of inflammation and tissue remodeling in the heart and blood vessels. The insights gained could lead to the development of innovative, individualized treatments, thereby improving outcomes for patients suffering from these debilitating diseases.

Abstract:

Title: The Extracellular Matrix as a Mediator of Cell-Cell Communication in Cardiovascular Inflammation (MATRICARD)

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), including coronary artery disease (CAD), myocardial infarction (MI), and heart failure, are the leading cause of morbidity and mortality globally, presenting a significant burden on healthcare systems in both industrialized and developing countries. The MATRICARD project seeks to elucidate the role of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in mediating cell-cell communication during the inflammatory processes underpinning these diseases.

Atherosclerosis, a chronic and sometimes acute inflammatory condition, is the underlying pathology in CAD and MI. It is characterized by the involvement of diverse cell types such as leukocytes, endothelial cells, vascular smooth muscle cells, platelets, fibroblasts, and cardiomyocytes. Genetic studies have found that variations in ECM proteins are associated with CVDs, suggesting that the ECM serves not only as a structural entity but also as a critical hub for communication and mechanical stimuli transduction.

The MATRICARD proposal aims to advance our understanding of the ECM proteome in sterile inflammatory diseases such as atherosclerosis and MI. The research objectives include exploring the ECM proteome, identifying novel regulators, studying molecular and cellular mechanisms that affect the disease course, and identifying potential therapeutic targets. By achieving these goals, MATRICARD intends to develop novel individualized treatment strategies and facilitate the translation of these findings into human clinical trials.

The project promises to deepen our knowledge of ECM-mediated cell-cell communication and reveal its translational potential in the treatment of CVDs. Through an innovative and multidisciplinary approach, MATRICARD aspires to push beyond current technical boundaries, offering hope for improved clinical outcomes for patients suffering from these debilitating diseases.

Abstract:

Title: The Extracellular Matrix as a Mediator of Cell-Cell Communication in Cardiovascular Inflammation

Cardiovascular diseases, including coronary artery disease (CAD), myocardial infarction (MI), and heart failure, represent the leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with atherosclerosis as the primary pathology. The project MATRICARD aims to dissect the intricate role of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in cardiovascular inflammation and its impact on disease progression. The ECM is not only a structural entity but also a dynamic and complex network that transmits mechanical stimuli and facilitates cell-cell communication—crucial in both chronic and acute phases of cardiovascular diseases.

Emerging evidence suggests that genetic variations affecting ECM proteins are strongly associated with cardiovascular diseases. This project proposes a comprehensive approach to explore the ECM proteome in the context of sterile inflammatory diseases such as atherosclerosis and MI. We will identify novel regulators and understand the underlying processes that govern cell-cell interactions and disease modulation—focusing on various cell types involved, including leukocytes, endothelial cells, vascular smooth muscle cells, platelets, fibroblasts, and cardiomyocytes.

The research aims to advance beyond current technical boundaries, deepen knowledge of ECM-mediated cell-cell communication, and reveal translational potential by identifying novel therapeutic targets. We anticipate that our findings will pave the way for the development of individualized treatment strategies and enable the translation of our findings to human clinical trials.

The MATRICARD project is poised to provide groundbreaking insights into the ECM's role in cardiovascular diseases and open new avenues for therapeutic interventions. The multidisciplinary approach combines cutting-edge proteomics, genetics, cell biology, and clinical research, setting the stage to revolutionize the management of cardiovascular inflammation and its sequelae.
